raw_text: The idea of a self-customizing IE system emerged recently with the improvement of pattern acquisition techniques (Sudo et al, 2003b), where the IE system customizes itself across domains given by the user? s query. Furthermore, there are demands for access to in formation in languages different from the user? s own
clean_text: The idea of a self-customizing IE system emerged recently with the improvement of pattern acquisition techniques (Sudo et al, 2003b), where the IE system customizes itself across domains given by the user's query.

citing_paper_authors: Kiyoshi, Sudo | Satoshi, Sekine | Ralph, Grishman
raw_text: (Sudo et al, 2003a)) consists of three phases to learn extraction patterns from the source documents for a scenario specified by the user. First, it applies morphological analysis ,dependency parsing and Named Entity (NE) tagging to the entire source document set, and converts all the sentences in the source document set into dependency trees
clean_text: (Sudo et al, 2003a) consists of three phases to learn extraction patterns from the source documents for a scenario specified by the user.

citing_paper_authors: Mark A., Greenwood | Mark, Stevenson
raw_text: An additional advantage of linked chain patterns is that they do not cause an unwieldy number of candidate patterns to begenerated unlike some other approaches for representing extraction patterns, such as the one pro posed by Sudo et al (2003) where any subtree of the dependency tree can act as a potential pattern. When used within IE systems these pat terns are generalised by replacing terms which refer to specific entities with a general semantic class
clean_text: An additional advantage of linked chain patterns is that they do not cause an unwieldy number of candidate patterns to be generated unlike some other approaches for representing extraction patterns, such as the one proposed by Sudo et al (2003) where any subtree of the dependency tree can act as a potential pattern.

citing_paper_authors: Idan, Szpektor | Hristo, Tanev | Ido, Dagan | Bonaventura, Coppola
raw_text: Three classes of syntactic template learning approaches are presented in the literature: learning of predicate argument templates (Yangarber et al, 2000), learning of syntactic chains (Lin and Pantel, 2001) and learning of sub-trees (Sudo et al, 2003)
clean_text: Three classes of syntactic template learning approaches are presented in the literature: learning of predicate argument templates (Yangarber et al, 2000), learning of syntactic chains (Lin and Pantel, 2001) and learning of sub-trees (Sudo et al, 2003).
